summary: The bill, titled the Revitalizing Downtowns and Main Streets Act, proposes an investment tax credit for converting non-residential buildings into affordable housing. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a 20% credit on qualified conversion expenditures. The bill outlines criteria for eligible buildings, defines 'qualified conversion,' sets expenditure thresholds, establishes a national credit limitation allocated among states, and includes provisions for progress expenditures and recapture. It also addresses state allocation plans and defines terms like "economically distressed area."
